title: American_Top_40_1977_February_5th
description:
"From the rocky coast of Maine to the sandy shores of Hawaii, you hear the nation's top hits every week at this time on American Top 40. The countdown doesn't stop until we get to our new number one best seller."



American Top 40 with Casey Kasem aired on radio from July 4, 1970 until August 6, 1988. This recording is a rebroadcast from internet radio.

In this countdown:

The band Kansas has its very first chart hit, "Carry On Wayward Son" (at number 36) and Elvis Presley has his 133rd top 40 hit.

A listener wants to know if there has ever been a group that hit number one, split up, and then had one of its ex-members hit number one. Casey says one group has had each of its members hit number one since its split, and gives the details.

There is a hit by a group who scored a chart first. In the 32 year history of the album chart, their album was the first ever to hit number one after being on the chart for an entire year.

Casey answers the question, "How many novelty songs in the rock era have hit number one, and which has been the biggest?" He says the top three contenders are a witch-doctor, a duck, and a chipmunk.

There is a band in the countdown where one member nearly electrocuted himself onstage during a show, but insisted the show continue and was playing again ten minutes later.

Finally, Casey recounts the origins of the popular television show, "American Bandstand."

37:    I Like To Do It - K.C. & The Sunshine Band
